defs.docs:
`requestty` (request-tty) is an easy-to-use collection of interactive cli prompts inspired by
 [Inquirer.js].

attributes.value: / `requestty` (request-tty) is an easy-to-use collection of interactive cli prompts inspired by
/ This crate is based on creating [`Question`]s, and then prompting them to the user. There are 10
/ in-built [`Question`]s, but if none of them fit your need, you can [create your own!](#custom-prompts)
/ See [`Question`] for more information on the builders.
/ Unlike the builder api, the macros can only be used to create a list of questions.
/ See [`questions`] and [`prompt_module`](prompt_module!) for more information on the macros.
/ [`Question`]s can be asked in 2 main ways.
/ - Using direct [functions](#functions) provided by the crate.
/       // Declare the questions you want to ask
/       // Declare the questions you want to ask
/   This is mainly useful if you need more control over prompting the questions, and using
/ See the documentation of [`Question`] for more information on the different in-built questions.
/ Terminal interaction is handled by 2 traits: [`Backend`] and [`EventIterator`].
/ The traits are already implemented and can be enabled with features for the following terminal
/ The default is `crossterm` for the following reasons:
/ If the crate's in-built prompts does not satisfy your needs, you can build your own custom
/ - `macros`: Enabling this feature will allow you to use the [`questions`] and
/ - `smallvec` (default): Enabling this feature will use [`SmallVec`] instead of [`Vec`] for [auto
/   completions]. This allows inlining single completions.
/ - `crossterm` (default): Enabling this feature will use the [`crossterm`](https://crates.io/crates/crossterm)
/   library for terminal interactions such as drawing and receiving events.
/ - `termion`: Enabling this feature will use the [`termion`](https://crates.io/crates/termion)
/   library for terminal interactions such as drawing and receiving events.
/ println!("Your password was: {}", answer.as_string().expect("password returns a string"));
/ For more examples, see the documentation for the various in-built questions, and the

defs.name: Answer
defs.value:
pub enum Answer {
    String(String),
    ListItem(ListItem),
    ExpandItem(ExpandItem),
    Int(i64),
    Float(f64),
    Bool(bool),
    ListItems(Vec<ListItem>),
}
defs.docs: The different answer types that can be returned by the [`Question`]s

attributes.value: / The different answer types that can be returned by the [`Question`]s

defs.name: Separator
defs.docs:
A separator is a _single line_ of text that can be used to annotate other choices. It is not
 selectable and is skipped over when users navigate.

attributes.value: / A separator is a _single line_ of text that can be used to annotate other choices. It is not
/ selectable and is skipped over when users navigate.
/ If the text is more than one line, it will be cut-off.

defs.name: EditorBuilder
defs.docs: The builder for the [`editor`] prompt.

attributes.value: / Once the user exits their editor, the contents of the temporary file are read in as the
/ result. The editor to use is determined by the `$VISUAL` or `$EDITOR` environment variables.
/ If neither of those are present, `vim` (for unix) or `notepad` (for windows) is used.
/ See the various methods for more details on each available option.
/     .message("Please enter a short description about yourself")

attributes.value: / Set a default value for the file

/ times will contain what was last written.

defs.name: ExpandBuilder
defs.docs: The builder for a [`expand`] prompt.

attributes.value: / The keys are ascii case-insensitive characters. The 'h' option is added by the prompt and
/ The choices are represented with the [`Choice`] enum. [`Choice::Choice`] can be multi-line,
/ but [`Choice::Separator`]s can only be single line.
/ See the various methods for more details on each available option.

defs.name: default
defs.docs: Set a default key for the expand

attributes.value: / Set a default key for the expand
/ If no key is entered by the user and they press `Enter`, the default key is used.
/ If `default` is unspecified, it defaults to the 'h' key.
/ If the default given is not a key to a choice it will cause a panic on [`build`]

defs.name: page_size
defs.docs: The maximum height that can be taken by the expanded list

attributes.value: / The maximum height that can be taken by the expanded list
/ If the total height exceeds the page size, the list will be scrollable.
/ The `page_size` must be a minimum of 5. If `page_size` is not set, it will default to 15. It
/ will only be used if the user expands the prompt.
/ It will panic if the `page_size` is less than 5.

defs.name: should_loop

attributes.value: / Whether to wrap around when user gets to the last element.
/ If `should_loop` is not set, it will default to `true`. It will only be used if the user

defs.name: page_size
defs.docs: The maximum height that can be taken by the [`auto_complete`] selection list

attributes.value: / The maximum height that can be taken by the [`auto_complete`] selection list
/ If the total height exceeds the page size, the list will be scrollable.
/ The `page_size` must be a minimum of 5. If `page_size` is not set, it will default to 15. It
/ will only be used if [`auto_complete`] is set, and returns more than 1 completions.
/ It will panic if the `page_size` is less than 5.

defs.name: Getter
defs.docs: Optionally dynamically get a value.

attributes.value: / It can either be a [`FnOnce`] that results in a value, or the value itself.
/ This should not need to be constructed manually, as it is used with the [`Into`] trait.

defs.name: Prompt
defs.docs: Prompts are a way to write custom [`Question`]s.

attributes.value: / Prompts are a way to write custom [`Question`]s.
/ The prompt is given a `message`, the previous [`Answers`] and a [`Backend`] and
/ [`EventIterator`]. Using these, it is responsible for doing everything from rendering to user
/ interaction. While no particular look is enforced, it is recommended to keep a similar look to
/ the rest of the in-built questions.
/ You can use the `requestty-ui` crate to build the prompts. You can see the implementations of
/ the in-built questions for examples on how to use it.

defs.name: build
defs.docs: Consumes the builder returning a [`Question`]

defs.name: Question
defs.docs: A `Question` that can be asked.

attributes.value: / - `name` (required): This is used as the key in [`Answers`].
/   It is not shown to the user unless `message` is unspecified.
/ - `message`: The message to display when the prompt is rendered in the terminal.
/   If it is not given, the `message` defaults to "\<name\>: ". It is recommended to set this as
/   `name` is meant to be a programmatic `id`.
/ - `when`: Whether to ask the question or not.
/   This can be used to have context based questions. If it is not given, it defaults to `true`.
/ - `ask_if_answered`: Prompt the question even if it is answered.
/   By default if an answer with the given `name` already exists, the question will be skipped.
/   This can be override by setting `ask_if_answered` is set to `true`.
/ A `Question` can be asked by creating a [`PromptModule`] or using [`prompt_one`] or

defs.name: editor
defs.docs: Prompt that takes launches the users preferred editor on a temporary file

attributes.value: / Prompt that takes launches the users preferred editor on a temporary file
/ Once the user exits their editor, the contents of the temporary file are read in as the
/ result. The editor to use is determined by the `$VISUAL` or `$EDITOR` environment variables.
/ If neither of those are present, `vim` (for unix) or `notepad` (for windows) is used.
/ See the various methods on the [`builder`] for more details on each available option.
/     .message("Please enter a short description about yourself")

defs.name: float

defs.name: expand
defs.docs: Prompt that allows the user to select from a list of options by key

attributes.value: / Prompt that allows the user to select from a list of options by key
/ The keys are ascii case-insensitive characters. The 'h' option is added by the prompt and
/ The choices are represented with the [`Choice`] enum. [`Choice::Choice`] can be multi-line,
/ but [`Choice::Separator`]s can only be single line.
/ See the various methods on the [`builder`] for more details on each available option.

defs.name: select
defs.docs: Prompt that allows the user to select from a list of options

attributes.value: / Prompt that allows the user to select from a list of options
/ The choices are represented with the [`Choice`] enum. [`Choice::Choice`] can be multi-line,
/ but [`Choice::Separator`]s can only be single line.
/ See the various methods on the [`builder`] for more details on each available option.

defs.name: raw_select
defs.docs: Prompt that allows the user to select from a list of options with indices

attributes.value: / Prompt that allows the user to select from a list of options with indices

/ but [`Choice::Separator`]s can only be single line.

defs.name: multi_select
defs.docs: Prompt that allows the user to select multiple items from a list of options

attributes.value: / Prompt that allows the user to select multiple items from a list of options
/ Unlike the other list based prompts, this has a per choice boolean default.
/ The choices are represented with the [`Choice`] enum. [`Choice::Choice`] can be multi-line,
/ but [`Choice::Separator`]s can only be single line.
/ See the various methods on the [`builder`] for more details on each available option.
